did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.origination: Collection assembled by the UCLA Library Special Collections.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of California, Los Angeles. Library Special Collections.

did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact UCLA Library Special Collections for paging information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], California ephemera collection (Collection 200). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

otherfindaid.head: Alternate Finding Aid Available
otherfindaid.p: In-house card catalog is available at UCLA Library Special Collections for consultation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of broadsides, clippings, brochures, and other ephemeral materials relating to California. Subjects include: abortion, Alcatraz Island, building and loan associations, California politics and government, Covina, drugs, Fort Ross, Greek-Americans, International Gay and Lesbian Archives, Japanese American National Museum, Hiram Johnson, William Kerckhoff, Los Angeles riots, motion picture theaters, Olympic Games, Rancho Santa Anita, Simon Wiesenthal Center, and others.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged alphabetically by subject.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.

did.unittitle: Great Black Americans : vol.1, no. 2 : postcards in full color.

did.unittitle: The Appomattox Country Club : the finest Colored recreational club resort in the world.

scopecontent.p: "Appomattox Country Club, 2330 Santa Ana Blvd. Phone JEfferson 9667 Los Angeles, California." Includes an inset map showing location of the Club and provides directions to the Club by both automobile and trolley. In the lower right hand corner is a "clip and mail" form to be filled out and sent into the Club for information on membership.

did.unittitle: The Black Panther Manifesto : the fascists have already decided in advance to murder Chairman Bobby Seale in the electric chair.

did.unittitle: Discover downtown L.A. : a 200th birthday gift to Los Angeles for children of all ages to explore and enjoy.

scopecontent.p: Includes an inset view of the Los Angeles basin from downtown to Santa Monica Bay featuring the region's freeways. Important commercial and cultural buildings are numbered on the view and illustrations of these buildings along with textual information are featured on the verso of the view. "Look up! Look up! Look up!"--Along upper left had side of view. Includes some historical facts about Los Angeles.

SEE: Los Angeles, Calif. - Watts Towers
Box 190 is an oversize flat box.

scopecontent.p: Illustrated brochure about Simon Rodia's Towers in Watts (Los Angeles, Calif.) and how to visit them.

Illustrated pamphlet about the Watts Labor Community Action Committee (WLCAC). The WLCAC attempted to beautify Watts and generate jobs and pride in the community among residents. Pamphlet specifically describes programs in farming and agriculture.

Folded, poster-size brochure including graphics, photographs, and articles related to the activities and mission of the Studio Watts Workshop. The Studio Watts Workshop was founded as a community arts organization by James Woods and Guy Miller in 1964. The original Workshop was located at 103rd Street and Grandee in South-East Los Angeles. The Studio Watts Workshop became the Watts Community Housing Corporation in 1969.
